name: The Causation Con
definition: Assuming that because one event followed another, the first event caused the second.
whyItWorks: Our brains are pattern-matching machines. When we see a sequence, we instinctively assign causation. 'After' feels like 'because'—even when many other factors could explain the outcome.

examples.text: Crime dropped after we increased deportations. Proof that deportation reduces crime.
examples.analysis: Many factors affect crime: economy, policing changes, demographics, drug market shifts. Correlation during a period doesn't establish causation.

examples.text: I started taking this supplement and felt better within a week. It definitely works!
examples.analysis: Could be placebo effect, lifestyle changes made simultaneously, natural recovery, or regression to the mean. Personal experience isn't controlled evidence.

examples.text: Since California reduced some sentences, crime increased. Soft-on-crime policies caused it.
examples.analysis: Many factors changed simultaneously: pandemic, economic stress, policing changes, drug market shifts. Attribution requires controlling for variables.

examples.text: Housing prices rose after remote work became common. Working from home caused the housing crisis.
examples.analysis: Many simultaneous factors: record-low interest rates, supply chain issues, investor activity, migration patterns. Remote work is one factor among many.

examples.text: After that celebrity endorsed this product, sales increased 500%. Celebrity endorsements are the most effective marketing.
examples.analysis: Could be timing, other marketing efforts, general trends, or product improvements. One data point isn't proof of general effectiveness.

promptStarters: After ___ happened, ___ followed. Clearly, the first caused the second.
Ever since we started ___, we've seen ___. Coincidence?
The numbers don't lie: ___ went up/down right after ___.
We tried ___ and ___ got better. It obviously works.
Look at what happened after ___—the results speak for themselves.
